So before we get too deep into material
animation, it's important to understand
the difference between a skeletal mesh
and a static mesh since it has a pretty
big performance impact. So skeletal
meshes have skeleton bones and skinning
which allows for bone based deformation.
So each vertex is influenced by one or
more bones. All this movement is
calculated on the CPU and this gives you
a lot of interactivity, but because it's
on the CPU, it's heavier on performance
and memory. Static meshes have no
skeleton. So they're just fixed geometry
and any animation is done purely
visually on the GPU. But the upside is
that they're super lightweight because
they b they benefit from GPU instancing.
So it can render a ton of them in a
single draw call which makes it ideal
for performanceheavy scenes like crowds

using static meshes is that they can be

material animation runs on the client
